Dear Jenifer Boyer:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on March 9, 2023 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental care
(2) A dental examination within 12 months prior to
admission shall be documented or there shall be an
examination not later than 90 calendar days following
admission.

Two of three youth files reviewed lacked dental examinations being completed
within 90 calendar days following admission to the facility or a dental examination
within 12 months prior to admission.
CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of
the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents’ needs, implementation of treatment plans,
and discharge of residents.
One of three employees files reviewed lacked Handle with Care refresher training
every six months per the facilities Physical Restraint internal policy and
procedure.
RFCJJ 2.11 Reentry/Aftercare Services
1) Level 1: Level 1 reentry/aftercare services to be
provided when the youth has services being provided
in the home by Community Mental Health (CMH) or
Prepaid Inpatient Health Plan (PIHP) or other services
approved by MDHHS juvenile justice program office.
d) Ensure initial contact with the youth/family is be
completed within five business days of release from the
facility.
ii. One contact per month must be made for the
remaining months.
One of two closed files reviewed did not have one contact per month as one
month was missed by the contracted provider that was providing the service for
the facility.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was not in need of technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Discussed the variance for Tuberculosis screening as the facility was
continuing to complete Tuberculous screenings annually on staff.

• Reviewed requirements for dental, educated the facility on the rule indicating if
a dental was completed within twelve months prior to admission to obtain the
documentation of this.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The CAP
was in response to the 2022 Interim Inspection dated April 12, 2022 where they
were found in non-compliance for rules 400.4113 (f-i, ii), (i) and (e) Employee
Records, 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers, and
RFCJJ 2.11 Reentry/Aftercare Services. A CAP was approved on May 4, 2022
and was effective as those violations were not repeated during this inspection.
Financial Overview
Teaching Family Homes annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending
September 30, 2021, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit, and resulting in
concerning financial condition. The results of the audit reported a negative total
net asset, negative working capital, a deficit of unrestricted net assets, and a ratio
of 0.54:1. The facility made some progress as the amount of negative total assets,
working capital, operating ratio, and unrestricted net assets are less than they
were in the previous 2020 audit however, the factors continue to indicate that the
facility is in a declining financial condition. A special investigation addressed these
concerns (Special Investigation 2022C0128039). During the Special Investigation,
documents were obtained including accounts Receivable Aging Summary as of
July 12, 2022, accounts Payable Aging Summary as of July 12, 2022, PPP Loan
Forgiveness documentation which reported loan forgiveness dated 5/4/2022,
statement of cash flows for October 2021 through June 2022, synergy applications
for the CARES program. These documents were provided to the Bureau of Audit
for further review. After review by the Bureau of Audit, the total net assets are
positive, and the working capital are positive with these changes. The Manager of
Audit and Review was not able to fully determine if the facility is completely stable
with this limited information. The annual third-party audit report for fiscal year
ending September 30, 2022, has not yet been issued for year.
PREA compliance
PREA Facility Audit Final Report dated 12/12/2022 was reviewed and the facility
was found in compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment

The Chief Administrator reported difficulty in compliance with R400.4147 being a
barrier as a result of COVID 19 pandemic, when dental facilities reopened, most if
not all of the dental providers within the area were not accepting new patients and
were not accepting straight Medicaid. Attempts were made regularly to find a
dental provider that accepted both new patients and Medicaid. The facility has
been able to secure a dental provider in Cheboygan, Michigan. The Chief
Administrator has faced challenges with obtaining qualified staff, position postings
are on Indeed, however the facility is not finding applicants that follow through with
the hiring process. The Chief Administrator identified barriers with the JJAU as the
facility is feeling pressured to take youth when the facility feels with the limited
services offered in the area are unable to meet the needs of particular youth.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three employees were interviewed during the onsite visit. All staff reported feeling
safe and supported in their job duties. The facility is short staffed however staff
report they are working together to ensure staffing needs. There were no
concerns noted by staff.
Three youth were interviewed during onsite visit. The youth interviewed reported
feeling safe, feeling respected, and treated well by staff. All the youth are
attending school onsite at the facility and receiving therapy twice a week. Youth
reported receiving three meals a day and snacks. Youth reported there is portion
sizes at the facility due to the USD guidelines. Youth reported they would like to be
able to eat as much as they would like.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was completed during the onsite visit. The facility
was clean, and no safety concerns were noted. Medications and cleaning
chemicals are stored appropriately. All bedrooms had appropriate bedding. The
kitchen was clean with the menu posted on the refrigerator. The facility had
emergency plans posted and the intent to check criminal history posted in the
entry of the facility.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
